awd_titl_txt: Exactly Solvable Stochastic Systems: Connections and Universality
awd_abstract_narration:
This project deals with large random systems, which can be typically described as collections of particles with certain prescribed rules of interactions. Examples are given by random stepped surfaces in three-dimensional space, random sorting networks, six-vertex model (also known as the square ice and used to model a thin planar layer of molecules of water). A distinguishing feature of the studied systems is the presence of numerous exact formulas, describing the probabilistic characteristics of the systems. The central questions concern asymptotic properties of the systems of growing sizes, and the research aims at exact rather than qualitative answers.

The project aims at two kinds of results. First, the new types of asymptotic behavior lead to discoveries of connections between stochastic systems of different origins, such as lattice models of two-dimensional statistical mechanics, random matrices, stochastic partial differential equations, and probability measures of asymptotic representation theory. Second, the development of robust methods leads to the extensions of the results from the exactly solvable cases to much wider universality classes, thus, justifying the use of these cases for the extensive peculiar predictions, potentially reaching the real-world applications. In particular, during the project the PI will investigate the transition between Gaussian Free Field and Gaussian fields solving hyperbolic SPDEs in the six-vertex model, connections between random sorting networks and eigenvalue distributions of random matrices, and the link between matrix elements of powers of random Hermitian matrices and the finite-time distribution of the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang SPDE.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of the project was to study large random objects and to unveil unexpected and deeply hidden connections between them. As one example, during the project we discovered that local behavior of random two dimensional surfaces (equivalently, random lozenge tilings) can be described by objects of the random matrix theory - by random eigenvalues of a Hermitian matrix from the so-called Gaussian Unitary Ensemble. Moreover, we have shown that this relation between two very different objects is not just an isolated artifact, but rather is present in a very wide generality. As an example of a very different nature, we also discovered a link between a classical distribution of random matrix theory (so-called Jacobi ensemble) and statistical tests for the presence of cointegration, which is a peculiar property of multidimensional time-series. Cointegration plays a prominent role in econometrics, and therefore our discovery has immediate applied relevance. We refer to the publications produced in the project for description of several other surprising relations.

In addition to scientific advances, the project produced a book "Lectures on random lozenge tilings", which is well-posed to become a to-go reference for many future publications and to help in educating future generations of researchers.

The project provided educational opportunities for junior researchers of all ages, ranging from high-school students and to advanced postdocs and assistant professors.
